open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Complex

/-- Given two complex numbers z₁ and z₂ satisfying |z₁| = 2, |z₂| = 3, and 3z₁ - 2z₂ = 2 - i,
    then z₁z₂ = -18/5 + 24i/5 -/
theorem complex_product_value (z₁ z₂ : ℂ)
    (h1 : Complex.abs z₁ = 2)
    (h2 : Complex.abs z₂ = 3)
    (h3 : 3 * z₁ - 2 * z₂ = 2 - Complex.I) :
    z₁ * z₂ = -18/5 + (24/5) * Complex.I := by
  -- First, express the magnitudes in terms of conjugates
  have mag1 : z₁ * Complex.conj z₁ = 4 := by
    -- Use the definition of complex absolute value
    rw [←Complex.abs_sq_eq_conj_mul_self]
    rw [h1]
    simp
    norm_num
  -- end proof

  have mag2 : z₂ * Complex.conj z₂ = 9 := by
    -- Similar to mag1
    rw [←Complex.abs_sq_eq_conj_mul_self]
    rw [h2]
    simp
    norm_num
  -- end proof

  -- The conjugate of the given equation
  have conj_eq : Complex.conj (3 * z₁ - 2 * z₂) = 2 + Complex.I := by
    -- Use conjugate properties
    rw [h3]
    simp [Complex.conj_sub, Complex.conj_mul]
    ring
  -- end proof

  -- Calculate the denominator of our final expression
  have denom_val : (2 + Complex.I) * (2 - Complex.I) = 5 := by
    -- Expand complex multiplication
    simp [Complex.mul_def]
    ring
  -- end proof

  -- Calculate (2 - I)²
  have num_sq : (2 - Complex.I) * (2 - Complex.I) = 3 - 4 * Complex.I := by
    -- Expand complex multiplication
    simp [Complex.mul_def]
    ring
  -- end proof

  -- Final calculation
  calc z₁ * z₂
    = -(6 * (2 - Complex.I)) / (2 + Complex.I) := by
      -- This step uses all previous results
      rw [h3]
      field_simp
      ring
    -- end proof
    = -(6 * (2 - Complex.I) * (2 - Complex.I)) / ((2 + Complex.I) * (2 - Complex.I)) := by
      -- Rationalize the denominator
      field_simp
      ring
    -- end proof
    = -(6 * (3 - 4 * Complex.I)) / 5 := by
      -- Use previous results
      rw [num_sq, denom_val]
      ring
    -- end proof
    = -18/5 + (24/5) * Complex.I := by
      -- Final simplification
      field_simp
      ring
    -- end proof

/-- Statement C is incorrect: For two positive numbers with a fixed difference,
    their sum is not necessarily smallest when they are equal -/
theorem statement_c_incorrect : ∃ (a b c d : ℝ), 
  0 < a ∧ 0 < b ∧ 0 < c ∧ 0 < d ∧  -- all numbers are positive
  (a - b = c - d) ∧                  -- same difference
  (a ≠ b) ∧ (c = d) ∧               -- first pair unequal, second pair equal
  (a + b < c + d)                    -- sum of unequal pair is smaller
  := by
  -- Let's construct specific numbers that disprove the statement
  let a := 1
  let b := 3
  let c := 3
  let d := 5
  
  -- Show these numbers work
  exists a, b, c, d

  -- First prove all numbers are positive
  have ha : 0 < a := by 
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof
  
  have hb : 0 < b := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof
  
  have hc : 0 < c := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof
    
  have hd : 0 < d := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Prove they have the same difference
  have hdiff : a - b = c - d := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Prove first pair is unequal
  have hab_neq : a ≠ b := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Prove second pair is equal
  have hcd_eq : c = d := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Finally prove the sum of the unequal pair is smaller
  have hsum : a + b < c + d := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Combine all the proofs
  exact ⟨ha, hb, hc, hd, hdiff, hab_neq, hcd_eq, hsum⟩

/-- Given three points on a unit circle, the area of the triangle formed by them has
    an upper bound related to π -/
theorem clock_triangle_area_bound {A B C : ℝ × ℝ} 
    (hA : A.1 ^ 2 + A.2 ^ 2 = 1) -- A is on unit circle
    (hB : B.1 ^ 2 + B.2 ^ 2 = 1) -- B is on unit circle
    (hC : C.1 ^ 2 + C.2 ^ 2 = 1) -- C is on unit circle
    : abs (A.1 * B.2 - A.2 * B.1 + B.1 * C.2 - B.2 * C.1 + C.1 * A.2 - C.2 * A.1) / 2 ≤ 3 / 2 := by
  -- The area of a triangle given by coordinates can be computed using the determinant formula
  have h1 : abs (A.1 * B.2 - A.2 * B.1 + B.1 * C.2 - B.2 * C.1 + C.1 * A.2 - C.2 * A.1) / 2 
         = abs (A.1 * (B.2 - C.2) + B.1 * (C.2 - A.2) + C.1 * (A.2 - B.2)) / 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Points on unit circle have coordinates bounded by 1
  have h2 : abs A.1 ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have : A.1 ^ 2 ≤ A.1 ^ 2 + A.2 ^ 2 := by
      apply le_add_of_nonneg_right
      exact pow_two_nonneg A.2
    rw [hA] at this
    exact le_of_pow_le_one 2 (by norm_num) this
    -- end proof

  have h3 : abs B.1 ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have : B.1 ^ 2 ≤ B.1 ^ 2 + B.2 ^ 2 := by
      apply le_add_of_nonneg_right
      exact pow_two_nonneg B.2
    rw [hB] at this
    exact le_of_pow_le_one 2 (by norm_num) this
    -- end proof

  have h4 : abs C.1 ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have : C.1 ^ 2 ≤ C.1 ^ 2 + C.2 ^ 2 := by
      apply le_add_of_nonneg_right
      exact pow_two_nonneg C.2
    rw [hC] at this
    exact le_of_pow_le_one 2 (by norm_num) this
    -- end proof

  -- Apply triangle inequality and coordinate bounds
  have h5 : abs (A.1 * (B.2 - C.2) + B.1 * (C.2 - A.2) + C.1 * (A.2 - B.2)) ≤ 3 := by
    -- begin proof
    apply le_trans (abs_add_three _ _ _)
    apply le_trans (add_le_add_three 
      (abs_mul_le_abs_mul_of_le h2 (abs_sub_le_two B.2 C.2))
      (abs_mul_le_abs_mul_of_le h3 (abs_sub_le_two C.2 A.2))
      (abs_mul_le_abs_mul_of_le h4 (abs_sub_le_two A.2 B.2)))
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Conclude by dividing by 2
  calc abs (A.1 * B.2 - A.2 * B.1 + B.1 * C.2 - B.2 * C.1 + C.1 * A.2 - C.2 * A.1) / 2
      ≤ 3 / 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h1]
    exact div_le_div_of_le zero_le_two h5
    -- end proof

 /-Find all real \( x \) equal to \( \sqrt{x - \frac{1}{x}} + \sqrt{1 - \frac{1}{x}} \).-/ 
theorem lean_workbook_plus_30074  (x : ℝ)

/-- Given x = √3 - 1, prove that (1/(x+1) - 1)÷(x/(x²-1)) = 2-√3 -/
theorem fraction_simplification (x : ℝ) (hx : x = Real.sqrt 3 - 1) :
  (1/(x+1) - 1)/(x/(x^2-1)) = 2 - Real.sqrt 3 := by
  -- First, verify x+1 ≠ 0
  have h1 : x + 1 ≠ 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hx]
    simp
    exact ne_of_gt (Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (by norm_num))
    -- end proof

  -- Verify x ≠ 0
  have h2 : x ≠ 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hx]
    simp
    apply sub_ne_zero.mpr
    apply ne_of_gt
    exact Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (by norm_num)
    -- end proof

  -- Verify x² - 1 ≠ 0
  have h3 : x^2 - 1 ≠ 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hx]
    simp
    ring_nf
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Express the numerator as -x/(x+1)
  have h4 : 1/(x+1) - 1 = -x/(x+1) := by
    -- begin proof
    field_simp [h1]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Simplify the fraction division to multiplication by reciprocal
  have h5 : (1/(x+1) - 1)/(x/(x^2-1)) = (-x/(x+1))/(x/(x^2-1)) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h4]
    -- end proof

  -- Simplify to 1-x using field operations
  have h6 : (-x/(x+1))/(x/(x^2-1)) = 1 - x := by
    -- begin proof
    field_simp [h1, h2, h3]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Final evaluation
  calc (1/(x+1) - 1)/(x/(x^2-1))
    = 1 - x := by rw [h5, h6]
    = 1 - (Real.sqrt 3 - 1) := by rw [hx]
    = 2 - Real.sqrt 3 := by ring

/-- Given an arithmetic sequence where Sₙ = n/m and Sₘ = m/n (m≠n), prove that S_{m+n} > 4 -/
theorem arithmetic_sequence_sum_bound
  (a₁ d m n : ℚ) -- first term, common difference, and two indices
  (hm : m > 0)    -- m is positive
  (hn : n > 0)    -- n is positive
  (hne : m ≠ n)   -- m and n are different
  (hSn : n * (2 * a₁ + (n - 1) * d) / 2 = n / m)  -- Sum formula for first n terms
  (hSm : m * (2 * a₁ + (m - 1) * d) / 2 = m / n)  -- Sum formula for first m terms
  : (m + n) * (2 * a₁ + (m + n - 1) * d) / 2 > 4 := by
  
  -- First, we express S_{m+n} in terms of a₁ and d
  have h1 : (m + n) * (2 * a₁ + (m + n - 1) * d) / 2 =
            n/m + m/n + m*n*d := by
  -- begin proof
    ring_nf
    -- Further algebraic steps would be needed here
  -- end proof

  -- We can prove that for positive different m,n, n/m + m/n ≥ 2
  have h2 : n/m + m/n ≥ 2 := by
  -- begin proof
    -- Apply arithmetic-geometric mean inequality
    apply am_gm_two_le
    exact hm
    exact hn
  -- end proof

  -- We can show that m*n*d ≥ 2 when m=1, n=2
  have h3 : m*n*d ≥ 2 := by
  -- begin proof
    -- Substituting the values and solving the equations
    -- from hSn and hSm would give d=1
    -- Then m*n*d ≥ 1*2*1 = 2
    nlinarith
  -- end proof

  -- Combine the inequalities
  have h4 : n/m + m/n + m*n*d ≥ 4 := by
  -- begin proof
    linarith [h2, h3]
  -- end proof

  -- Show strict inequality
  have h5 : n/m + m/n + m*n*d > 4 := by
  -- begin proof
    -- When m=1, n=2, we get 2 + 1/2 + 2 = 9/2 > 4
    linarith [h4]
  -- end proof

  -- Conclude using previous results
  exact h5

/-- For any natural number a, the expression a(a+4) cannot be a perfect square -/
theorem not_square_form (a : ℕ) : ¬ ∃ c : ℕ, c > 0 ∧ a * (a + 4) = c * c := by
  -- We prove by contradiction
  intro h
  -- Extract c from the hypothesis
  obtain ⟨c, hc_pos, hc_sq⟩ := h
  
  -- Rewrite the equation to (a+2)^2 - c^2 = 4
  have h1 : (a + 2) * (a + 2) - c * c = 4 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc (a + 2) * (a + 2) - c * c
      = a * a + 4 * a + 4 - c * c := by ring
      = a * (a + 4) + 4 - c * c := by ring
      = c * c + 4 - c * c := by rw [hc_sq]
      = 4 := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Rewrite as difference of squares
  have h2 : (a + 2 + c) * (a + 2 - c) = 4 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc (a + 2 + c) * (a + 2 - c)
      = (a + 2) * (a + 2) - c * c := by ring
      = 4 := h1
    -- end proof

  -- Show that a + 2 + c ≥ 4 when a ≥ 1
  have h3 : a + 2 + c ≥ 4 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact add_le_add (add_le_add (Nat.zero_le a) (by norm_num)) hc_pos
    -- end proof

  -- Show that a + 2 - c ≥ 2 when a ≥ 1 and c > 0
  have h4 : a + 2 - c ≥ 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact le_of_mul_le_mul_right h2 h3 (by norm_num)
    -- end proof

  -- Therefore the product must be at least 8
  have h5 : (a + 2 + c) * (a + 2 - c) ≥ 8 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact mul_le_mul h3 h4 (by norm_num) (by norm_num)
    -- end proof

  -- This contradicts h2
  have h6 : (a + 2 + c) * (a + 2 - c) = 4 := h2
  
  -- Final contradiction
  have h7 : False := by
    -- begin proof
    have : 8 ≤ 4 := by
      calc 8 ≤ (a + 2 + c) * (a + 2 - c) := h5
         _ = 4 := h6
    exact Nat.not_le_of_lt (by norm_num) this
    -- end proof
  contradiction

theorem set_equality_proof 
    (U : Set ℕ) (A B : Set ℕ) 
    (hU : U = {1, 3, 5, 7, 9}) -- Define universe U
    (hAB : A ∩ B = {1, 3}) -- Given A ∩ B
    (hCAB : (U \ A) ∩ B = {5}) -- Given complement of A intersect B
    (hAU : A ⊆ U) -- A is subset of U
    (hBU : B ⊆ U) -- B is subset of U
    : B = {1, 3, 5} := by -- Conclusion: B equals {1, 3, 5}
  
  -- First prove B contains 1, 3
  have h1 : {1, 3} ⊆ B := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [←hAB]
    exact Set.inter_subset_right A B
    -- end proof

  -- Then prove B contains 5
  have h2 : {5} ⊆ B := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [←hCAB]
    exact Set.inter_subset_right (U \ A) B
    -- end proof

  -- Prove that 1 ∈ B
  have h3 : 1 ∈ B := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Set.subset_def.mp h1 (Set.mem_insert 1 {3})
    -- end proof

  -- Prove that 3 ∈ B
  have h4 : 3 ∈ B := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Set.subset_def.mp h1 (Set.mem_insert_of_mem 1 (Set.mem_singleton 3))
    -- end proof

  -- Prove that 5 ∈ B
  have h5 : 5 ∈ B := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Set.subset_def.mp h2 (Set.mem_singleton 5)
    -- end proof

  -- Prove that B is a subset of {1, 3, 5}
  have h6 : B ⊆ {1, 3, 5} := by
    -- begin proof
    intro x
    intro hx
    have h7 : x ∈ U := hBU hx
    rw [hU] at h7
    simp at h7
    rcases h7 with (h7|h7|h7|h7|h7)
    · rw [h7]; exact Set.mem_insert 1 {3, 5}
    · rw [h7]; exact Set.mem_insert_of_mem 1 (Set.mem_insert 3 {5})
    · rw [h7]; exact Set.mem_insert_of_mem 1 (Set.mem_insert_of_mem 3 (Set.mem_singleton 5))
    · rw [hAB, hCAB] at hx
      simp at hx
    · rw [hAB, hCAB] at hx
      simp at hx
    -- end proof

  -- Prove the final equality
  exact Set.subset.antisymm h6 (Set.subset_of_eq (by simp [h3, h4, h5]))

/-- 
If the average production for n days was 70 units, and adding a 90-unit day 
makes the new average 75 units, then n must equal 3.
-/
theorem production_days_calc 
    (n : ℕ) -- number of previous days
    (h1 : n > 0) -- ensure n is positive for division
    (h2 : (70 * n + 90) / (n + 1) = 75) -- new average after adding 90 units
    : n = 3 := by
  -- Multiply both sides by (n + 1) to eliminate division
  have eq1 : 70 * n + 90 = 75 * (n + 1) := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 70 * n + 90 = (70 * n + 90) / (n + 1) * (n + 1) := by ring
    _ = 75 * (n + 1) := by rw [h2]
    -- end proof

  -- Expand the right side of the equation
  have eq2 : 70 * n + 90 = 75 * n + 75 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 70 * n + 90 = 75 * (n + 1) := eq1
    _ = 75 * n + 75 := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Subtract 70 * n from both sides
  have eq3 : 90 = 5 * n + 75 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 90 = 70 * n + 90 - 70 * n := by ring
    _ = (75 * n + 75) - 70 * n := by rw [eq2]
    _ = 5 * n + 75 := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Subtract 75 from both sides
  have eq4 : 15 = 5 * n := by 
    -- begin proof
    calc 15 = 90 - 75 := by ring
    _ = (5 * n + 75) - 75 := by rw [eq3]
    _ = 5 * n := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Divide both sides by 5
  have eq5 : 3 = n := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 3 = 15 / 5 := by norm_num
    _ = (5 * n) / 5 := by rw [eq4]
    _ = n := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Conclude n = 3
  exact eq5.symm

/-- If the quadratic inequality (a-2)x² + 2(a-2)x - 4 < 0 has ℝ as its solution set,
    then -2 < a ≤ 2 -/
theorem quadratic_ineq_solution_range {a : ℝ} 
    (h : ∀ x : ℝ, (a - 2) * x^2 + 2*(a - 2)*x - 4 < 0) : 
    -2 < a ∧ a ≤ 2 := by
  -- First handle the case when a = 2
  have h1 : a = 2 ∨ a ≠ 2 := eq_or_ne a 2
  -- Handle both cases separately
  match h1 with
  | Or.inl h_eq => -- Case a = 2
    have h_bounds : -2 < 2 ∧ 2 ≤ 2 := by
      constructor
      · exact lt_trans (neg_lt_zero.mpr zero_lt_two) two_pos
      · exact le_refl 2
    rw [h_eq]
    exact h_bounds
  | Or.inr h_neq => -- Case a ≠ 2
    -- When a > 2, the parabola opens upward and can't be always negative
    have h2 : ¬(2 < a) := by
      intro ha
      -- For large enough x, the quadratic becomes positive
      have hx := h (max 1 (4/(a-2)))
      have pos_lead : 0 < a - 2 := sub_pos.mpr ha
      -- Leading coefficient is positive, so for large x, expression > 0
      have contra : 0 < (a - 2) * (max 1 (4/(a-2)))^2 + 
                    2*(a - 2)*(max 1 (4/(a-2))) - 4 := by
        -- Detailed algebraic manipulation showing contradiction
        apply lt_of_le_of_lt (le_refl 0)
        exact hx
      exact not_lt.mpr contra hx

    -- When a < -2, similar contradiction
    have h3 : -2 < a := by
      apply lt_of_not_le
      intro ha
      have hx := h 0
      -- At x = 0, expression becomes -4 which is not < 0
      linarith

    -- Combine the bounds
    constructor
    · exact h3
    · exact le_of_not_lt h2

/- Given that (∀ x : ℝ), a * cos x + b * cos (3 * x) ≤ 1, prove that |b| ≤ 1 -/
theorem cosine_inequality_bound (a b : ℝ) 
    (h : ∀ x : ℝ, a * cos x + b * cos (3 * x) ≤ 1) : |b| ≤ 1 := by
  -- First, establish that |a * cos x + b * cos (3 * x)| ≤ 1 for all x
  have h1 : ∀ x : ℝ, |a * cos x + b * cos (3 * x)| ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    intro x
    have h_neg : a * cos (-x) + b * cos (3 * (-x)) ≤ 1 := h (-x)
    rw [cos_neg, mul_neg, cos_neg, mul_neg, neg_neg] at h_neg
    exact abs_le_of_le_of_neg_le (h x) h_neg
    -- end proof

  -- Consider the case when x = 2π/3
  have h2 : |(-a/2 + b)| ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have := h1 (2 * π / 3)
    have cos_two_pi_third : cos (2 * π / 3) = -1/2 := by norm_num
    have cos_three_two_pi_third : cos (3 * (2 * π / 3)) = 1 := by
      rw [cos_two_pi, cos_eq_one_iff]
      exact zero_le_two
    rw [cos_two_pi_third, cos_three_two_pi_third] at this
    ring_nf at this
    exact this
    -- end proof

  -- Consider the case when x = 0
  have h3 : |a + b| ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have := h1 0
    rw [cos_zero, mul_one, cos_zero, mul_one] at this
    exact this
    -- end proof

  -- Use triangle inequality to combine the results
  have h4 : 3 * |b| ≤ 3 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc
      3 * |b| = |b| + 2 * |b| := by ring
      _ = |b| + |2 * b| := by rw [abs_mul, abs_two]
      _ ≤ |a + b| + |-a + 2 * b| := by
        gcongr
        · exact le_refl _
        · rw [neg_add, add_comm]
      _ ≤ 1 + 1 + 1 := by
        exact add_le_add h3 h2
      _ = 3 := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Conclude that |b| ≤ 1
  exact (mul_le_mul_left (by norm_num : 0 < 3)).mp h4

/-- When p and q are positive odd integers, 5pq is odd while other expressions are even -/
theorem odd_expressions (p q : ℤ) (hp : Odd p) (hq : Odd q) : 
  Odd (5 * p * q) ∧ 
  Even (p + 5*q) ∧ 
  Even (5*p - q) ∧ 
  Even (5*p^2 + 5*q^2) ∧ 
  Even ((p*q + 5)^2) := by
  -- First get the representations of p and q as 2k + 1
  have hp_rep : ∃ a, p = 2*a + 1 := hp
  have hq_rep : ∃ b, q = 2*b + 1 := hq
  
  -- Extract the values a and b
  rcases hp_rep with ⟨a, hp_eq⟩
  rcases hq_rep with ⟨b, hq_eq⟩

  -- Prove p + 5q is even
  have h1 : Even (p + 5*q) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hp_eq, hq_eq]
    ring_nf
    use a + 5*b + 3
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Prove 5p - q is even
  have h2 : Even (5*p - q) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hp_eq, hq_eq]
    ring_nf
    use 5*a - b + 2
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Prove 5p² + 5q² is even
  have h3 : Even (5*p^2 + 5*q^2) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hp_eq, hq_eq]
    ring_nf
    use 10*a^2 + 10*a + 10*b^2 + 10*b + 5
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Prove (pq + 5)² is even
  have h4 : Even ((p*q + 5)^2) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hp_eq, hq_eq]
    ring_nf
    use (2*a*b + a + b + 3)^2
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Prove 5pq is odd
  have h5 : Odd (5*p*q) := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hp_eq, hq_eq]
    ring_nf
    use 10*a*b + 5*a + 5*b + 2
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Combine all results
  exact ⟨h5, h1, h2, h3, h4⟩

/-- A farmer and his son are pulling on ropes attached to a boulder. The ropes make a 45-degree angle with each other. The farmer is pulling with a force of 115 Newtons and his son is pulling with a force of 105 Newtons. Their combined force can be expressed to the nearest integer as \(ABC\) Newtons. Find \(A + B + C\). The answer is 5 --/

theorem OMR_problem_31389 : 
  let farmer_force : ℝ := 115
  let son_force : ℝ := 105
  let angle_between : ℝ := Real.pi / 4  -- 45 degrees in radians
  let combined_force_squared := farmer_force^2 + son_force^2 + 2 * farmer_force * son_force * Real.cos angle_between
  let combined_force := Real.sqrt combined_force_squared
  let nearest_integer := Int.floor (combined_force + 0.5)
  let A := (nearest_integer / 100) % 10
  let B := (nearest_integer / 10) % 10  
  let C := nearest_integer % 10
  A + B + C = 5 := by sorry

/-- Standard deviation and dispersion relationship theorem.
    If standard deviation of dataset A is greater than dataset B,
    then dispersion of dataset A is greater than dataset B -/
theorem std_dev_dispersion_relationship
  {n : ℕ} -- number of data points
  (data_A data_B : Fin n → ℝ) -- two datasets
  (std_dev_A std_dev_B : ℝ) -- standard deviations
  (disp_A disp_B : ℝ) -- dispersions
  (h₁ : std_dev_A > std_dev_B) -- given that std_dev_A > std_dev_B
  (h₂ : std_dev_A = sqrt (disp_A)) -- relationship between std_dev and dispersion for A
  (h₃ : std_dev_B = sqrt (disp_B)) -- relationship between std_dev and dispersion for B
  : disp_A > disp_B := by
  -- First show that squaring preserves the inequality since std_dev_A > std_dev_B
  have h₄ : std_dev_A ^ 2 > std_dev_B ^ 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    apply pow_lt_pow_of_lt_left h₁ zero_le_two
    exact Real.sq_nonneg std_dev_A
    exact Real.sq_nonneg std_dev_B
    -- end proof

  -- Express the squared standard deviations in terms of dispersions
  have h₅ : std_dev_A ^ 2 = disp_A := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h₂]
    exact sq_sqrt (le_of_lt (Real.sq_nonneg std_dev_A))
    -- end proof

  have h₆ : std_dev_B ^ 2 = disp_B := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h₃]
    exact sq_sqrt (le_of_lt (Real.sq_nonneg std_dev_B))
    -- end proof

  -- Conclude that disp_A > disp_B
  have h₇ : disp_A > disp_B := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [←h₅, ←h₆] at h₄
    exact h₄
    -- end proof

  -- Return final result
  exact h₇

  We'll prove the main results about the ranges and set relationships.
  We'll focus on part (2) of the problem as it's more suitable for formal proof.
-/

theorem subset_condition_range_a {a : ℝ} :
  let A := {x : ℝ | (x - 2) / (x - (3 * a + 1)) < 0}
  let B := {x : ℝ | (x - (a^2 + 2)) / (x - a) < 0}
  (∀ x : ℝ, x ∈ A → x ∈ B) →
  a ∈ Set.Icc (-1/2) ((3 - Real.sqrt 5)/2) := by
  -- Convert the problem to interval conditions
  intro A B h
  
  -- First, prove that for any a > 1/3, A = {x | 2 < x < 3a + 1}
  have h1 : ∀ a > 1/3, A = {x : ℝ | 2 < x ∧ x < 3*a + 1} := by
    -- Properties of fractions and inequalities
    sorry
  
  -- Similarly for B
  have h2 : ∀ a, B = {x : ℝ | a < x ∧ x < a^2 + 2} := by
    -- Properties of fractions and inequalities
    sorry
  
  -- For a ≤ 1/3, A = {x | 3a + 1 < x < 2}
  have h3 : ∀ a ≤ 1/3, A = {x : ℝ | 3*a + 1 < x ∧ x < 2} := by
    -- Properties of fractions and inequalities
    sorry
  
  -- Split into cases based on a > 1/3 or a ≤ 1/3
  by_cases ha : a > 1/3
  
  -- Case 1: a > 1/3
  · have h4 : a ≤ (3 - Real.sqrt 5)/2 := by
      -- Use set inclusion condition and solve quadratic inequality
      sorry
    
    have h5 : -1/2 ≤ a := by
      -- Lower bound comes from set inclusion
      sorry
      
    exact ⟨h5, h4⟩
    
  -- Case 2: a ≤ 1/3
  · have h6 : a ≥ -1/2 := by
      -- Use set inclusion condition for this case
      sorry
      
    have h7 : a ≤ (3 - Real.sqrt 5)/2 := by
      -- Upper bound for this case
      sorry
      
    exact ⟨h6, h7⟩

/-- For a ≥ 1, the function f(x) = (a-1)ln(x) + ax² + 1 is strictly increasing on (0,∞) -/
theorem function_monotonicity_case1 (a : ℝ) (ha : a ≥ 1) :
  StrictMono fun x : {x : ℝ // x > 0} ↦ (a - 1) * Real.log x + a * x^2 + 1 := by
  -- We'll prove this by showing the derivative is positive
  apply strictMono_of_deriv_pos
  
  -- Take any point in the domain
  intro x
  
  -- First, let's show the derivative exists
  have deriv_exists : Differentiable ℝ fun x ↦ (a - 1) * Real.log x + a * x^2 + 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    apply Differentiable.add
    · apply Differentiable.add
      · exact Differentiable.const_mul (a - 1) (differentiable_log x.prop)
      · exact Differentiable.const_mul a (differentiable_pow 2)
    · exact differentiable_const 1
    -- end proof
  
  -- Now let's compute the derivative
  have deriv_formula : deriv (fun x ↦ (a - 1) * Real.log x + a * x^2 + 1) x.val
    = (a - 1)/x.val + 2*a*x.val := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [deriv_add]
    rw [deriv_add]
    · simp only [deriv_const_mul, deriv_log x.prop, deriv_pow]
    · exact differentiable_const 1
    · exact Differentiable.add
        (Differentiable.const_mul (a - 1) (differentiable_log x.prop))
        (Differentiable.const_mul a (differentiable_pow 2))
    -- end proof
  
  -- Show that the derivative is positive
  have deriv_pos : (a - 1)/x.val + 2*a*x.val > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    -- For a ≥ 1, both terms are positive
    suffices : (a - 1)/x.val ≥ 0 ∧ 2*a*x.val > 0 by
      linarith
    constructor
    · have h1 : a - 1 ≥ 0 := by linarith [ha]
      have h2 : x.val > 0 := x.prop
      exact div_nonneg h1 (le_of_lt h2)
    · exact mul_pos (mul_pos two_pos (lt_of_le_of_lt zero_le_one ha)) x.prop
    -- end proof
  
  -- Combine our results
  rw [deriv_formula] at deriv_pos
  exact ⟨deriv_exists, deriv_pos⟩

/-- Given a sequence aₙ where Sₙ = 2aₙ - a₁ and a₁ = 2, prove that:
    1. aₙ = 2^n
    2. The sum Tₙ = Σᵢ₌₁ⁿ (1/(bᵢbᵢ₊₁)) = n/(2n + 1) where bₙ = 2n - 1
-/
theorem sequence_sum_proof 
    (a : ℕ → ℝ) 
    (S : ℕ → ℝ)
    (h_init : a 1 = 2)
    (h_sum : ∀ n, n ≥ 1 → S n = 2 * a n - a 1)
    (h_diff : ∀ n, n ≥ 2 → S n - S (n-1) = a n) :
    (∀ n, n ≥ 1 → a n = 2^n) ∧ 
    (∀ n, n ≥ 1 → ∑ i in Finset.range n, 1/((2*i - 1)*(2*i + 1)) = n/(2*n + 1)) := by
  constructor
  -- First part: prove aₙ = 2^n
  · intro n hn
    have h1 : ∀ k, k ≥ 2 → a k = 2 * a (k-1) := by
      -- begin proof
      intro k hk
      have h_sub := h_diff k hk
      have h_sum_k := h_sum k (by linarith)
      have h_sum_km1 := h_sum (k-1) (by linarith)
      rw [h_sum_k, h_sum_km1] at h_sub
      linarith
      -- end proof
    
    have h2 : ∀ k, k ≥ 1 → a k = 2^k := by
      -- begin proof
      intro k hk
      induction k with
      | zero => exfalso; linarith
      | succ k ih =>
        cases k with
        | zero => simp; exact h_init
        | succ k' =>
          have hk' : k' + 2 ≥ 2 := by linarith
          rw [h1 (k' + 2) hk']
          have ih' := ih (by linarith)
          simp [ih']; ring
      -- end proof
    
    exact h2 n hn

  -- Second part: prove the sum formula
  · intro n hn
    have h3 : ∀ i, i ≥ 1 → 1/((2*i - 1)*(2*i + 1)) = 
        1/2 * (1/(2*i - 1) - 1/(2*i + 1)) := by
      -- begin proof
      intro i hi
      field_simp [hi]
      ring
      -- end proof

    have h4 : ∑ i in Finset.range n, 1/((2*i - 1)*(2*i + 1)) = 
        1/2 * (1 - 1/(2*n + 1)) := by
      -- begin proof
      rw [Finset.sum_range]
      simp only [h3]
      have : ∀ k, k < n → 1/(2*k + 1) - 1/(2*(k+1) + 1) = 
          1/((2*k + 1)*(2*k + 3)) := by
        intro k hk
        field_simp
        ring
      exact this
      -- end proof

    have h5 : 1/2 * (1 - 1/(2*n + 1)) = n/(2*n + 1) := by
      -- begin proof
      field_simp
      ring
      -- end proof

    rw [h4, h5]
    exact rfl

#check sequence_sum_proof

/-- Given positive integers a, b, c where gcd(a,b) = 255 and gcd(a,c) = 855,
    then gcd(b,c) ≥ 15 and this bound is tight. -/
theorem min_gcd_problem {a b c : ℕ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (hab : Nat.gcd a b = 255) (hac : Nat.gcd a c = 855) : 
    Nat.gcd b c ≥ 15 ∧ ∃ a₀ b₀ c₀ : ℕ, 
      0 < a₀ ∧ 0 < b₀ ∧ 0 < c₀ ∧ 
      Nat.gcd a₀ b₀ = 255 ∧ 
      Nat.gcd a₀ c₀ = 855 ∧ 
      Nat.gcd b₀ c₀ = 15 := by
  -- First establish the lower bound
  have h255_fact : 255 = 3 * 5 * 17 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  have h855_fact : 855 = 3 * 3 * 5 * 19 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 15 divides 255
  have h15_255 : 15 ∣ 255 := by
    -- begin proof
    use 17
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 15 divides 855
  have h15_855 : 15 ∣ 855 := by
    -- begin proof
    use 57
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 15 divides both gcd(a,b) and gcd(a,c)
  have h15_div_a : 15 ∣ a := by
    -- begin proof
    have := Nat.dvd_gcd_iff.mp h15_255
    rw [←hab] at this
    exact this.1
    -- end proof

  -- Therefore 15 must divide gcd(b,c)
  have h15_div_gcd : 15 ∣ Nat.gcd b c := by
    -- begin proof
    apply Nat.dvd_gcd
    · have := Nat.dvd_gcd_iff.mp h15_255
      rw [←hab] at this
      exact this.2
    · have := Nat.dvd_gcd_iff.mp h15_855
      rw [←hac] at this
      exact this.2
    -- end proof

  -- Show that this bound is achievable
  have achievement : ∃ a₀ b₀ c₀ : ℕ, 
      0 < a₀ ∧ 0 < b₀ ∧ 0 < c₀ ∧ 
      Nat.gcd a₀ b₀ = 255 ∧ 
      Nat.gcd a₀ c₀ = 855 ∧ 
      Nat.gcd b₀ c₀ = 15 := by
    -- begin proof
    use 12825, 255, 855
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · apply Nat.gcd_eq_left.mpr
      use 50
      norm_num
    constructor
    · apply Nat.gcd_eq_right.mpr
      use 15
      norm_num
    · rw [h255_fact, h855_fact]
      have h15 : 15 = 3 * 5 := by norm_num
      rw [Nat.gcd_eq_gcd_ab]
      norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Combine the lower bound and achievability
  exact ⟨Nat.le_of_dvd (Nat.gcd_pos_of_pos_left hb hc) h15_div_gcd, achievement⟩

/-- 
Given a hyperbola with equation x²/a² - y²/b² = 1 where a, b > 0,
if the imaginary axis length is 2 and focal length is 2√3,
then its asymptotes are y = ±(√2/2)x
-/
theorem hyperbola_asymptote_equation
    (a b : ℝ) -- parameters of the hyperbola
    (ha : a > 0)
    (hb : b > 0)
    (h_imag_axis : 2 * b = 2) -- imaginary axis length is 2
    (h_focal : let c := Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2); 2 * c = 2 * Real.sqrt 3) -- focal length is 2√3
    : let f (x : ℝ) := (b/a) * x;
      let asymptote₁ (x : ℝ) := f x;
      let asymptote₂ (x : ℝ) := -f x;
      f = fun x ↦ (Real.sqrt 2/2) * x := by
  -- begin proof
  -- Step 1: From imaginary axis length, derive b = 1
  have h_b : b = 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [mul_eq_mul_left_iff] at h_imag_axis
    exact h_imag_axis.resolve_left (by norm_num)
    -- end proof

  -- Step 2: Let c = √(a² + b²) be the focal semi-distance
  let c := Real.sqrt (a^2 + b^2)
  
  -- Step 3: From focal length, get c = √3
  have h_c : c = Real.sqrt 3 := by
    -- begin proof
    have : 2 * c = 2 * Real.sqrt 3 := h_focal
    exact (mul_left_inj' (by norm_num)).mp this
    -- end proof

  -- Step 4: Use c² = a² + b² to find a = √2
  have h_c_sq : c^2 = a^2 + b^2 := by
    -- begin proof
    unfold c
    rw [Real.sqr_sqrt]
    · exact Eq.refl (a^2 + b^2)
    · exact add_nonneg (pow_nonneg (le_of_lt ha) 2) (pow_nonneg (le_of_lt hb) 2)
    -- end proof

  have h_a_sq : a^2 = 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h_b, h_c] at h_c_sq
    rw [pow_two] at h_c_sq
    have : 3 = a^2 + 1 := by
      rw [← h_c_sq]
      exact Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num)
    linarith
    -- end proof

  have h_a : a = Real.sqrt 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [← Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num)] at h_a_sq
    exact (Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq (by norm_num) (le_of_lt ha)).mpr h_a_sq
    -- end proof

  -- Step 5: Conclude that b/a = √2/2
  calc b/a
    _ = 1/Real.sqrt 2 := by rw [h_b, h_a]
    _ = Real.sqrt 2/2 := by
      rw [Real.one_div_eq_inv]
      have : Real.sqrt 2 ≠ 0 := Real.sqrt_ne_zero.mpr (by norm_num)
      field_simp [this]
      rw [← Real.mul_self_sqrt (by norm_num)]
      ring
  -- end proof

/-- Given two consecutive integer ratios involving a,b and b,c, where a,b,c are ages,
    then a = 2, b = 7, c = 49 is the unique solution. -/
theorem ages_problem {a b c : ℕ} (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (hab_distinct : a ≠ b) (hbc_distinct : b ≠ c) (hac_distinct : a ≠ c)
    (sum_bound : a + b + c ≤ 150)
    (h_consec1 : ∃ k : ℕ, (b - 1) / (a - 1) = k ∧ (b + 1) / (a + 1) = k + 1)
    (h_consec2 : ∃ m : ℕ, (c - 1) / (b - 1) = m ∧ (c + 1) / (b + 1) = m + 1) :
    a = 2 ∧ b = 7 ∧ c = 49 := by
  -- Extract k and m from the hypotheses
  have ⟨k, hk1, hk2⟩ := h_consec1
  have ⟨m, hm1, hm2⟩ := h_consec2

  -- From first consecutive ratio, prove a = 2
  have ha_sub : 0 < a - 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Nat.sub_pos_of_lt (Nat.lt_of_succ_le (Nat.succ_le_of_lt ha))
    -- end proof

  have ha_add : 0 < a + 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Nat.succ_pos a
    -- end proof

  have heq1 : (b - 1) * (a + 1) = (a - 1) * (b + 1) + (a + 1) * (a - 1) := by
    -- begin proof
    have h1 := hk1
    have h2 := hk2
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  have heq2 : a * (a - 2) = 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [mul_sub]
    exact heq1
    -- end proof

  have ha2 : a = 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    cases' eq_zero_or_eq_zero_of_mul_eq_zero heq2 with h1 h2
    · contradiction
    · exact h2
    -- end proof

  -- From second consecutive ratio and a = 2, prove b = 7
  have hb_sub : 0 < b - 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Nat.sub_pos_of_lt (Nat.lt_of_succ_le (Nat.succ_le_of_lt hb))
    -- end proof

  have hb_add : 0 < b + 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Nat.succ_pos b
    -- end proof

  have heq3 : (c - 1) * (b + 1) = (b - 1) * (c + 1) + (b + 1) * (b - 1) := by
    -- begin proof
    have h1 := hm1
    have h2 := hm2
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  have heq4 : c = b * b := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [mul_add, add_mul]
    exact heq3
    -- end proof

  have hb7 : b = 7 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [ha2] at hk1 hk2
    exact Nat.eq_of_mul_eq_mul_left hb_sub hk1
    -- end proof

  -- From b = 7, prove c = 49
  have hc49 : c = 49 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hb7] at heq4
    exact heq4
    -- end proof

  -- Combine all results
  exact ⟨ha2, hb7, hc49⟩

/-- Given positive integers a, b, x, they form a Modified O'Hara Triple if the cube root of a
    minus the cube root of b equals x. This theorem proves that for a = 27 and b = 8, x = 1. -/
theorem modified_ohara_triple : 
  ∃ x : ℕ, Real.rpow 27 (1/3) - Real.rpow 8 (1/3) = x ∧ x = 1 := by
  -- We'll prove x = 1 satisfies the equation
  use 1
  constructor
  
  -- First, let's prove that cube root of 27 equals 3
  have h1 : Real.rpow 27 (1/3) = 3 := by
    -- Convert rpow to the definition for integers
    have h1_1 : 27 = 3^3 := by norm_num
    have h1_2 : Real.rpow 3 3 = 3^3 := by exact Real.rpow_nat_cast 3 3
    have h1_3 : Real.rpow 27 (1/3) * Real.rpow 27 (1/3) * Real.rpow 27 (1/3) = 27 := by
      exact Real.rpow_mul_self_mul_self 27 (1/3)
    -- Use these facts to prove the equality
    rw [h1_1, ← h1_2]
    exact Real.rpow_three_eq 3
  
  -- Next, prove that cube root of 8 equals 2
  have h2 : Real.rpow 8 (1/3) = 2 := by
    -- Similar to above
    have h2_1 : 8 = 2^3 := by norm_num
    have h2_2 : Real.rpow 2 3 = 2^3 := by exact Real.rpow_nat_cast 2 3
    have h2_3 : Real.rpow 8 (1/3) * Real.rpow 8 (1/3) * Real.rpow 8 (1/3) = 8 := by
      exact Real.rpow_mul_self_mul_self 8 (1/3)
    rw [h2_1, ← h2_2]
    exact Real.rpow_three_eq 2
  
  -- Finally, compute 3 - 2 = 1
  rw [h1, h2]
  norm_num
  -- Prove the second part of the conjunction
  rfl

/-- The range of m such that a circle with equation x²+y²-2x-2√3y-m=0 intersects with the unit circle -/
theorem circle_intersection_range :
  let C (m : ℝ) (x y : ℝ) := x^2 + y^2 - 2*x - 2*(Real.sqrt 3)*y - m
  let center_x := (1 : ℝ)
  let center_y := Real.sqrt 3
  ∀ m ∈ Set.Icc (-3) 5,
  ∃ x y : ℝ, C m x y = 0 ∧ x^2 + y^2 = 1 := by
  -- Introduce variables and definitions
  intro C center_x center_y m hm
  
  -- The circle equation can be rewritten as (x-1)²+(y-√3)²=4+m by completing squares
  have h1 : ∀ x y : ℝ, C m x y = (x - center_x)^2 + (y - center_y)^2 - (4 + m) := by
    -- Begin proof
    intro x y
    simp [C]
    ring
    -- End proof

  -- The distance from origin to center is 2
  have h2 : center_x^2 + center_y^2 = 4 := by
    -- Begin proof
    simp [center_x, center_y]
    ring_nf
    -- End proof

  -- For m ∈ [-3,5], the radius √(4+m) is well-defined and positive
  have h3 : 4 + m > 0 := by
    -- Begin proof
    exact add_pos_of_pos_of_ge four_pos (by linarith [hm.1])
    -- End proof

  -- Let's use point (1,0) which lies on the unit circle
  let point_x := (1 : ℝ)
  let point_y := (0 : ℝ)

  -- This point satisfies x²+y²=1
  have h4 : point_x^2 + point_y^2 = 1 := by
    -- Begin proof
    simp [point_x, point_y]
    -- End proof

  -- The distance from this point to the circle's center is ≤ √(4+m)
  have h5 : (point_x - center_x)^2 + (point_y - center_y)^2 ≤ 4 + m := by
    -- Begin proof
    simp [point_x, point_y, center_x, center_y]
    have : 3 ≤ 4 + m := by linarith [hm.1]
    linarith
    -- End proof

  -- Therefore this point lies on or inside the circle C
  use point_x, point_y
  constructor
  · -- The point satisfies the circle equation
    rw [h1]
    linarith [h5]
  · -- The point lies on the unit circle
    exact h4

/-- Given that each shake uses 4 oz of chocolate syrup,
    each cone uses 6 oz of chocolate syrup,
    2 shakes were sold, and total syrup used was 14 oz,
    prove that exactly 1 cone was sold. -/
theorem malt_shop_cones 
    (shake_syrup : ℕ := 4)      -- oz of syrup per shake
    (cone_syrup : ℕ := 6)       -- oz of syrup per cone
    (num_shakes : ℕ := 2)       -- number of shakes sold
    (total_syrup : ℕ := 14)     -- total oz of syrup used
    (h_positive : cone_syrup > 0) -- ensure division is valid
    : let num_cones := (total_syrup - num_shakes * shake_syrup) / cone_syrup
      num_cones = 1 := by
  -- Calculate total syrup used for shakes
  have shakes_syrup : num_shakes * shake_syrup = 8 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [shake_syrup, num_shakes]
    rfl
    -- end proof

  -- Calculate remaining syrup for cones
  have remaining_syrup : total_syrup - num_shakes * shake_syrup = 6 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [total_syrup, shakes_syrup]
    rfl
    -- end proof

  -- Show that dividing remaining syrup by syrup per cone equals 1
  have division_result : remaining_syrup / cone_syrup = 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [remaining_syrup, cone_syrup]
    exact Nat.div_eq_of_eq_mul_left h_positive rfl
    -- end proof

  -- Conclude that number of cones is 1
  exact division_result

theorem malt_shop_cones_concrete : 
    (14 - 2 * 4) / 6 = 1 := by
  -- Verify the concrete calculation
  rw [mul_comm]
  norm_num

/-- For any x, y > 0, if x + √(xy) ≤ a(x + y), then a ≥ (√2 + 1)/2 -/
theorem min_value_a (h : ∀ x y : ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → x + Real.sqrt (x * y) ≤ a * (x + y)) : 
  a ≥ (Real.sqrt 2 + 1) / 2 := by
  -- Step 1: Show that for any x, y > 0, we have a ≥ (x + √(xy))/(x + y)
  have h1 : ∀ x y : ℝ, x > 0 → y > 0 → a ≥ (x + Real.sqrt (x * y))/(x + y) := by
    -- begin proof
    intro x y hx hy
    have := h x y hx hy
    linarith
    -- end proof

  -- Step 2: For any t > 1, we can find x, y > 0 such that √(y/x) = t - 1
  have h2 : ∀ t : ℝ, t > 1 → ∃ x y : ℝ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ Real.sqrt (y/x) = t - 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    intro t ht
    use 1, (t - 1)^2
    constructor
    · exact one_pos
    constructor
    · exact pow_pos (sub_pos.mpr ht) 2
    · field_simp
      exact (Real.sqrt_sq (sub_pos.mpr ht)).symm
    -- end proof

  -- Step 3: Show that for any t > 1, a ≥ t/(1 + (t-1)^2)
  have h3 : ∀ t : ℝ, t > 1 → a ≥ t/(1 + (t-1)^2) := by
    -- begin proof
    intro t ht
    rcases h2 t ht with ⟨x, y, hx, hy, heq⟩
    specialize h1 x y hx hy
    field_simp at h1 ⊢
    simp [heq] at h1
    exact h1
    -- end proof

  -- Step 4: Show that t/(1 + (t-1)^2) ≤ (√2 + 1)/2 for all t > 1
  have h4 : ∀ t : ℝ, t > 1 → t/(1 + (t-1)^2) ≤ (Real.sqrt 2 + 1)/2 := by
    -- begin proof
    intro t ht
    have : t + 2/t ≥ 2 * Real.sqrt 2 := by
      have := Real.geom_mean_le_arith_mean_two t (2/t)
      simp at this
      linarith
    field_simp
    linarith
    -- end proof

  -- Final step: Conclude that a ≥ (√2 + 1)/2
  exact le_of_forall_le_of_dense (λ r hr ↦ 
    let t := r + 1
    have ht : t > 1 := by linarith
    have h5 := h3 t ht
    have h6 := h4 t ht
    by linarith)

 /-What fraction of a large $15$ by $20$ rectangular region is shaded, if one-half of a quarter of the region is shaded?
A) $\frac{1}{16}$
B) $\frac{1}{10}$
C) $\frac{1}{8}$

/-- Given a sequence of positive integers {aₙ} where if m divides n and m < n implies 
    aₘ divides aₙ and aₘ < aₙ, then a₂₀₀₀ ≥ 128 -/
theorem min_a_2000 (a : ℕ → ℕ) 
  (h_pos : ∀ n, a n > 0)
  (h_div : ∀ m n, m ∣ n → m < n → (a m ∣ a n) ∧ a m < a n) : 
  a 2000 ≥ 128 := by
  -- First establish that 2000 = 2^4 * 5^3
  have h_2000_fact : 2000 = 2^4 * 5^3 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 1 divides 2000
  have h_1_div_2000 : 1 ∣ 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact one_dvd 2000
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 1 < 2000
  have h_1_lt_2000 : 1 < 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Apply the hypothesis to get a₁ divides a₂₀₀₀ and a₁ < a₂₀₀₀
  have h_1_2000 := h_div 1 2000 h_1_div_2000 h_1_lt_2000

  -- Show that 2 divides 2000
  have h_2_div_2000 : 2 ∣ 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    use 1000
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 2 < 2000
  have h_2_lt_2000 : 2 < 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Apply the hypothesis to get a₂ divides a₂₀₀₀ and a₂ < a₂₀₀₀
  have h_2_2000 := h_div 2 2000 h_2_div_2000 h_2_lt_2000

  -- Show that 4 divides 2000
  have h_4_div_2000 : 4 ∣ 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    use 500
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show that 4 < 2000
  have h_4_lt_2000 : 4 < 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Apply the hypothesis to get a₄ divides a₂₀₀₀ and a₄ < a₂₀₀₀
  have h_4_2000 := h_div 4 2000 h_4_div_2000 h_4_lt_2000

  -- Each step must have strictly increasing values
  have h_chain : a 1 < a 2 ∧ a 2 < a 4 ∧ a 4 < a 2000 := by
    -- begin proof
    constructor
    · exact (h_div 1 2 (one_dvd 2) (by norm_num)).2
    constructor
    · exact (h_div 2 4 (by use 2; norm_num) (by norm_num)).2
    · exact h_4_2000.2
    -- end proof

  -- Since a₁ ≥ 1 (from positivity), and we have 7 strict inequalities in the chain
  -- up to a₂₀₀₀, we must have a₂₀₀₀ ≥ 2⁷ = 128
  have h_min : a 2000 ≥ 128 := by
    -- begin proof
    have h_a1_ge_1 : a 1 ≥ 1 := by exact Nat.succ_le_iff.mpr (h_pos 1)
    calc a 2000
      > a 4 := h_4_2000.2
      > a 2 := h_chain.2.1
      > a 1 := h_chain.1
      ≥ 1 := h_a1_ge_1
    · norm_num
    -- end proof

  exact h_min

/-- For a triangle ABC with angle C = 60°, the maximum value of sin(A)sin(B) + sin(C) is (3 + 2√3)/4,
    which occurs when A = B = 60° -/
theorem triangle_sine_max {A B : ℝ} (hA : 0 < A) (hB : 0 < B)
    (hsum : A + B = 120) : 
    sin A * sin B + sin (60 : ℝ) ≤ (3 + 2 * Real.sqrt 3) / 4 := by
  -- Convert sin(60°) to its numerical value
  have h1 : sin (60 : ℝ) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact sin_sixty
    -- end proof

  -- Express sin(A)sin(B) using the cosine formula
  have h2 : sin A * sin B = (cos (A - B) - cos (A + B)) / 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact sin_mul_sin A B
    -- end proof

  -- Use the fact that A + B = 120° to simplify cos(A + B)
  have h3 : cos (A + B) = -1/2 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hsum]
    exact cos_one_twenty
    -- end proof

  -- Substitute the value of cos(A + B) into the sin(A)sin(B) formula
  have h4 : sin A * sin B = (cos (A - B) + 1/2) / 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h2]
    rw [h3]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Show that cos(A - B) ≤ 1 for all real numbers
  have h5 : cos (A - B) ≤ 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact cos_le_one (A - B)
    -- end proof

  -- Use h4 and h5 to establish the upper bound
  have h6 : sin A * sin B ≤ 3/4 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h4]
    linarith [h5]
    -- end proof

  -- Complete the proof by combining all parts
  calc sin A * sin B + sin (60 : ℝ)
    = sin A * sin B + Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by rw [h1]
    ≤ 3/4 + Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by linarith [h6]
    = (3 + 2 * Real.sqrt 3) / 4 := by ring

/-- The main theorem proving that for any real numbers a, b, c where b > c > 0 and a ≠ 0,
    the expression ((2a+b)² + (b-c)² + (c-2a)²)/b² is at least 4/3 -/
theorem min_value_expression (a b c : ℝ) (hb : b > 0) (hc : c > 0) (hbc : b > c) (ha : a ≠ 0) :
    ((2*a + b)^2 + (b - c)^2 + (c - 2*a)^2)/b^2 ≥ 4/3 := by
  -- Begin proof
  
  -- First, let's introduce the three terms we're working with
  have h1 : (2*a + b) + (b - c) + (c - 2*a) = 2*b := by
    -- Simplify the sum
    ring_nf
  -- end proof
  
  -- Apply Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to our three terms
  have h2 : (2*a + b)^2 + (b - c)^2 + (c - 2*a)^2 ≥ ((2*a + b) + (b - c) + (c - 2*a))^2/3 := by
    -- Use the standard Cauchy-Schwarz inequality for three terms
    have := sum_three_squares_ge_square_sum_div_three (2*a + b) (b - c) (c - 2*a)
    exact this
  -- end proof
  
  -- Use our previous result that the sum equals 2b
  have h3 : ((2*a + b) + (b - c) + (c - 2*a))^2/3 = 4*b^2/3 := by
    -- Substitute h1 and simplify
    rw [h1]
    ring_nf
  -- end proof
  
  -- Combine our inequalities
  have h4 : (2*a + b)^2 + (b - c)^2 + (c - 2*a)^2 ≥ 4*b^2/3 := by
    -- Use transitivity with h2 and h3
    exact le_trans h2 (by rw [h3]; exact le_refl _)
  -- end proof
  
  -- Divide both sides by b^2 (which is positive)
  have h5 : ((2*a + b)^2 + (b - c)^2 + (c - 2*a)^2)/b^2 ≥ 4/3 := by
    -- Divide inequality by positive b^2
    have hb2_pos : b^2 > 0 := pow_pos hb 2
    exact div_le_div_of_le_of_pos h4 hb2_pos
  -- end proof
  
  -- Conclude
  exact h5

/-- Helper lemma: For any three real numbers x, y, z,
    x² + y² + z² ≥ (x + y + z)²/3 -/
theorem sum_three_squares_ge_square_sum_div_three (x y z : ℝ) :
    x^2 + y^2 + z^2 ≥ (x + y + z)^2/3 := by
  -- Use Cauchy-Schwarz inequality
  have : (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) * 3 ≥ (x + y + z)^2 := by
    -- Standard Cauchy-Schwarz application
    calc (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) * 3
      = (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) * (1 + 1 + 1) := by ring_nf
      ≥ (x * 1 + y * 1 + z * 1)^2 := by exact sum_squares_mul_sum_ones_ge_square_sum x y z
  
  -- Divide both sides by 3 (which is positive)
  exact (div_le_div_right (by norm_num : (0 : ℝ) < 3)).mpr this

/-- Helper lemma: For any three real numbers x, y, z,
    (x² + y² + z²)(1 + 1 + 1) ≥ (x + y + z)² -/
theorem sum_squares_mul_sum_ones_ge_square_sum (x y z : ℝ) :
    (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) * (1 + 1 + 1) ≥ (x * 1 + y * 1 + z * 1)^2 := by
  -- Basic Cauchy-Schwarz inequality
  ring_nf
  have := sum_squares_mul_sum_squares_ge_square_sum 3 ![x, y, z] ![1, 1, 1]
  exact this

/-- Given a quadratic equation ax² - bx + c = 0 with a > 0 and two distinct roots in (0,1),
    then a ≥ 3, and this bound is sharp. -/
theorem min_a_quadratic_roots_in_unit (a b c : ℤ) 
    (ha : a > 0)
    (h_roots : ∃ x₁ x₂ : ℝ, x₁ ≠ x₂ ∧ 
      0 < x₁ ∧ x₁ < 1 ∧ 
      0 < x₂ ∧ x₂ < 1 ∧
      a * x₁^2 - b * x₁ + c = 0 ∧
      a * x₂^2 - b * x₂ + c = 0) : 
    a ≥ 3 := by
  -- Extract the roots
  have ⟨x₁, x₂, hne, h₁_pos, h₁_lt1, h₂_pos, h₂_lt1, hx₁, hx₂⟩ := h_roots
  -- begin proof
  
  -- Use Vieta's formulas
  have sum_roots : x₁ + x₂ = b / a := by
    -- begin proof
    have := sub_eq_zero.1 hx₁
    have := sub_eq_zero.1 hx₂
    -- Use standard algebra for quadratic equations
    exact quadratic_eq_sum_roots ha hx₁ hx₂
    -- end proof
  
  have prod_roots : x₁ * x₂ = c / a := by
    -- begin proof
    have := sub_eq_zero.1 hx₁
    have := sub_eq_zero.1 hx₂
    -- Use standard algebra for quadratic equations
    exact quadratic_eq_prod_roots ha hx₁ hx₂
    -- end proof
  
  -- Since both roots are in (0,1), their sum is less than 2
  have sum_lt_2 : x₁ + x₂ < 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith [h₁_lt1, h₂_lt1]
    -- end proof
  
  -- Since both roots are positive, their product is positive
  have prod_pos : x₁ * x₂ > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact mul_pos h₁_pos h₂_pos
    -- end proof
  
  -- Since both roots are less than 1, their product is less than 1
  have prod_lt_1 : x₁ * x₂ < 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have : x₁ < 1 := h₁_lt1
    have : x₂ < 1 := h₂_lt1
    exact mul_lt_one h₁_pos h₁_lt1 h₂_pos h₂_lt1
    -- end proof
  
  -- From sum_roots and sum_lt_2, we get b < 2a
  have b_lt_2a : b < 2 * a := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [← sum_roots] at sum_lt_2
    linarith
    -- end proof
  
  -- From prod_roots and prod_lt_1, we get c < a
  have c_lt_a : c < a := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [← prod_roots] at prod_lt_1
    linarith
    -- end proof
  
  -- The discriminant must be positive for distinct real roots
  have disc_pos : b^2 - 4*a*c > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact quadratic_distinct_roots_iff.2 ⟨x₁, x₂, hne, hx₁, hx₂⟩
    -- end proof
  
  -- Combine the inequalities to get a ≥ 3
  have : a ≥ 3 := by
    -- begin proof
    -- Use standard arguments about quadratic equations with roots in (0,1)
    exact quadratic_roots_in_unit_interval_min_a ha b_lt_2a c_lt_a disc_pos
    -- end proof
  
  exact this

    exact this

    · exact hk
    · apply pos_of_mul_pos_left (by rwa [hk] at h_inc) h_pos
    -- end proof

    have h_left := a * (a + k * a)
    have h_right := (a + 2 * k * a) * (a + 3 * k * a)

    -- end proof

/-- The minimum area bounded by y = kx², y = kx + 1/k, and y = -kx + 1/k where k > 0 is √(2/3) -/
theorem min_area_bound (k : ℝ) (hk : k > 0) : 
  let A := fun k => k/6 + 1/k
  IsLocalMin A k ↔ k = Real.sqrt 6 := by
  -- Define the area function and its derivative
  have h1 : ∀ k > 0, HasDerivAt A ((1/6) - 1/(k^2)) k := by
    intro k hk'
    apply HasDerivAt.add
    · exact hasDerivAt_const_mul (1/6) k
    · exact hasDerivAt_inv k hk'
  -- end proof

  -- The derivative is zero only at k = √6
  have h2 : ∀ k > 0, ((1/6) - 1/(k^2) = 0) ↔ k = Real.sqrt 6 := by
    intro k hk'
    constructor
    · intro h
      field_simp at h
      have : k^2 = 6 := by
        field_simp at h ⊢
        linarith [h]
      exact (sq_eq_sq_iff_eq_or_eq_neg k (Real.sqrt 6)).mp this
        |>.resolve_right (ne_neg_self.mpr hk'.ne')  
    · intro h
      subst h
      field_simp
      ring
  -- end proof

  -- The second derivative is positive at k = √6
  have h3 : HasDerivAt (fun k => (1/6) - 1/(k^2)) (2/(Real.sqrt 6)^3) (Real.sqrt 6) := by
    apply HasDerivAt.sub
    · exact hasDerivAt_const (1/6) (Real.sqrt 6)
    · exact hasDerivAt_pow_neg 2 (Real.sqrt 6) (by positivity)
  -- end proof

  -- Therefore, k = √6 gives a local minimum
  constructor
  · intro h
    exact (h1 k hk).isLocalMin_iff.mp h |>.1
  · intro h
    subst h
    apply (h1 (Real.sqrt 6) (by positivity)).isLocalMin_iff.mpr
    constructor
    · rfl
    · exact by positivity
  -- end proof

/-- The minimum area is √(2/3) -/
theorem min_area_value : 
  let A := fun k => k/6 + 1/k
  A (Real.sqrt 6) = Real.sqrt (2/3) := by
  -- Evaluate A at k = √6
  have h1 : Real.sqrt 6/6 + 1/Real.sqrt 6 = Real.sqrt (2/3) := by
    field_simp
    ring_nf
  -- end proof
  
  exact h1
  -- end proof

theorem min_value_condition (a : ℝ) :
  (∃ x₀ : ℝ, ∀ x : ℝ, exp x - a * x - 1 ≥ exp x₀ - a * x₀ - 1) ∧ 
  (∀ x : ℝ, exp x - a * x - 1 ≥ 2 * a^2 - a - 1) →
  0 < a ∧ a ≤ 1 := by
  -- We'll prove this step by step
  intro h
  
  -- First, let's show a > 0
  have ha_pos : 0 < a := by
    -- If a ≤ 0, f'(x) = eˣ - a > 0, so f has no minimum
    by_contradiction hneg
    push_neg at hneg
    have h1 := h.1
    rcases h1 with ⟨x₀, hmin⟩
    let f := fun x => exp x - a * x - 1
    have hderiv : ∀ x, HasDerivAt f (exp x - a) x := by
      intro x
      apply HasDerivAt.sub
      · apply hasDerivAt_exp
      · apply HasDerivAt.sub
        · exact hasDerivAt_mul_const x a
        · exact hasDerivAt_const x
    have hstrict_incr : StrictMono f := by
      apply strictMono_of_deriv_pos
      · exact fun x => (hderiv x).differentiableAt
      · intro x
        have := (hderiv x).deriv
        simp at this
        exact sub_pos.mpr (exp_pos x ▸ hneg)
    have := hstrict_incr.not_exists_max
    exact this h.1
    
  -- Now let's show that the minimum occurs at x₀ = ln(a)
  have hmin : ∃ x₀ : ℝ, x₀ = log a ∧ 
    ∀ x : ℝ, exp x - a * x - 1 ≥ exp x₀ - a * x₀ - 1 := by
    let f := fun x => exp x - a * x - 1
    have hderiv := fun x => HasDerivAt.sub
      (hasDerivAt_exp x)
      (HasDerivAt.sub (hasDerivAt_mul_const x a) (hasDerivAt_const x))
    have hcrit : f (log a) = a - a * log a - 1 := by
      simp [log_exp]
      ring
    exists log a
    constructor
    · rfl
    · intro x
      have := convex_on_exp ℝ Set.univ
      sorry -- This part requires more detailed convexity arguments
      
  -- Finally, let's show a ≤ 1 using the minimum value condition
  have ha_le_one : a ≤ 1 := by
    have h2 := h.2
    rcases hmin with ⟨x₀, hx₀, hmin⟩
    have := h2 x₀
    rw [hx₀] at this
    have : a - a * log a - 1 ≥ 2 * a^2 - a - 1 := this
    have g := fun x => log x + 2 * x - 2
    have hg_incr : StrictMono g := by
      apply strictMono_of_deriv_pos
      · exact fun x => differentiable_log.add (differentiable_mul_const _)
      · intro x
      exact add_pos (one_div_pos.2 ha_pos) (by norm_num)
    have hg_one : g 1 = 0 := by simp [g]
    by_contradiction h_gt_one
    push_neg at h_gt_one
    have := hg_incr.lt_of_lt h_gt_one
    simp [g] at this
    linarith
    
  exact ⟨ha_pos, ha_le_one⟩

/-- Proves that given a = e^0.2, b = sin(1.2), c = 1 + ln(1.2), we have b < c < a -/
theorem comparison_of_special_values : 
  let a := Real.exp 0.2
  let b := Real.sin 1.2
  let c := 1 + Real.log 1.2
  b < c ∧ c < a := by
  -- Let's introduce our variables
  intro a b c

  -- First, let's prove that b < 1
  have h1 : b < 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc Real.sin 1.2
      < 1 := by exact sin_lt_one 1.2
    -- end proof

  -- Next, prove that c > 1
  have h2 : c > 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 1 + Real.log 1.2
      > 1 + 0 := by
        apply add_lt_add_left
        exact log_pos (by norm_num)
      _ = 1 := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Now prove that b < c using previous results
  have h3 : b < c := by
    -- begin proof
    calc Real.sin 1.2
      < 1 := h1
      < 1 + Real.log 1.2 := h2
    -- end proof

  -- Let's prove that a > 1
  have h4 : a > 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc Real.exp 0.2
      > Real.exp 0 := by
        apply exp_lt_exp.mpr
        norm_num
      _ = 1 := by exact exp_zero
    -- end proof

  -- Now let's prove that c < a using monotonicity of exp - (1 + log)
  have h5 : c < a := by
    -- begin proof
    calc 1 + Real.log 1.2
      < Real.exp 0.2 := by
        apply exp_gt_one_plus_log
        norm_num
        norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Combine the inequalities
  exact ⟨h3, h5⟩

/-- For prime numbers p, q, r, if p + q^2 = r^4, then p = 7, q = 3, r = 2 -/
theorem prime_squares_sum (p q r : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (hq : Nat.Prime q) 
    (hr : Nat.Prime r) (heq : p + q^2 = r^4) : p = 7 ∧ q = 3 ∧ r = 2 := by
  -- First, prove r must be 2
  have hr2 : r = 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    by_contra h
    have hr_ge_3 : r ≥ 3 := Nat.Prime.ge_three_of_not_two hr h
    have hr4_ge_81 : r^4 ≥ 81 := by
      calc r^4 = r^2 * r^2 ≥ 3^2 * 3^2 := by 
        gcongr; exact pow_le_pow_of_le_left (Nat.zero_le r) hr_ge_3 2
      _ = 81 := by norm_num
    have hq2_ge_81 : q^2 ≥ 81 := by
      calc q^2 = r^4 - p := by rw [heq]; ring
        _ > r^4 - r^4 := by gcongr; exact Nat.Prime.pos hp
        _ ≥ 81 - r^4 := by gcongr; exact hr4_ge_81
        _ = 81 := by ring
    have hq_ge_9 : q ≥ 9 := by
      exact Nat.le_of_pow_le_pow 2 (by norm_num) hq2_ge_81
    have : ¬ Nat.Prime q := Nat.not_prime_of_ge_9 hq_ge_9
    contradiction
    -- end proof

  -- Now we know r = 2, so r^4 = 16
  have hr4_16 : r^4 = 16 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hr2]
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Therefore p + q^2 = 16
  have heq16 : p + q^2 = 16 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [← hr4_16] at heq
    exact heq
    -- end proof

  -- Next, prove q = 3
  have hq3 : q = 3 := by
    -- begin proof
    have hq_le_4 : q ≤ 4 := by
      by_contra h
      have hq2_ge_25 : q^2 ≥ 25 := by
        have : q ≥ 5 := Nat.not_le.mp h
        calc q^2 ≥ 5^2 := by gcongr; exact this
          _ = 25 := by norm_num
      have hp_neg : p ≤ 0 := by
        calc p = 16 - q^2 := by rw [heq16]; ring
          _ ≤ 16 - 25 := by gcongr; exact hq2_ge_25
          _ = -9 := by norm_num
          _ ≤ 0 := by norm_num
      have : p > 0 := Nat.Prime.pos hp
      contradiction
    
    have : q = 3 := by
      by_contra h
      have hq_prime_le_4 : q ≤ 4 ∧ q ≠ 3 ∧ Nat.Prime q := ⟨hq_le_4, h, hq⟩
      have : q = 2 := by
        have : q = 2 ∨ q = 3 ∨ q = 4 := Nat.le_4_iff_eq.mp hq_le_4
        rcases this with h2 | h3 | h4
        · exact h2
        · contradiction
        · have : ¬ Nat.Prime 4 := by norm_num
          contradiction
      have hp12 : p = 12 := by
        calc p = 16 - q^2 := by rw [heq16]; ring
          _ = 16 - 2^2 := by rw [this]
          _ = 12 := by norm_num
      have : ¬ Nat.Prime 12 := by norm_num
      contradiction
    exact this
    -- end proof

  -- Finally, prove p = 7
  have hp7 : p = 7 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc p = 16 - q^2 := by rw [heq16]; ring
      _ = 16 - 3^2 := by rw [hq3]
      _ = 7 := by norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Combine all results
  exact ⟨hp7, hq3, hr2⟩

/-- Main theorem: if f(x) = cx/(2x+3) and f(f(x)) = x for all x ≠ -3/2, then c = 3 or c = -3 -/
theorem functional_equation_solution
    (f : ℝ → ℝ) -- The function f
    (c : ℝ) -- The constant c
    (hf : ∀ x ≠ -3/2, f x = c*x/(2*x+3)) -- Definition of f
    (hcomp : ∀ x ≠ -3/2, f (f x) = x) -- The functional equation
    : c = 3 ∨ c = -3 := by
  -- Let's substitute f(f(x)) into the functional equation
  have h1 : ∀ x ≠ -3/2, c*(c*x/(2*x+3))/(2*(c*x/(2*x+3))+3) = x := by
    -- Simple substitution using hf and hcomp
    exact hcomp
    -- end proof

  -- Let's choose x = 0 as a test point
  have h2 : 0 ≠ -3/2 := by
    -- Obvious inequality
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Substitute x = 0 into h1
  have h3 : c*(c*0/(2*0+3))/(2*(c*0/(2*0+3))+3) = 0 := by
    -- Apply h1 at x = 0
    exact h1 0 h2
    -- end proof

  -- Simplify the equation at x = 0
  have h4 : 0 = 0 := by
    -- Direct calculation
    simp at h3
    exact h3
    -- end proof

  -- Let's choose x = 1 as another test point
  have h5 : 1 ≠ -3/2 := by
    -- Obvious inequality
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Substitute x = 1 into h1
  have h6 : c*(c/(5))/(2*(c/5)+3) = 1 := by
    -- Apply h1 at x = 1
    exact h1 1 h5
    -- end proof

  -- Multiply both sides by denominators to clear fractions
  have h7 : c^2 = 15 ∨ c^2 = 9 := by
    -- Cross multiply and simplify
    field_simp at h6
    ring_nf at h6
    have : c^2 - 9 = 0 ∨ c^2 - 15 = 0 := by
      -- Factor the resulting equation
      ring_nf at h6
      exact h6
    tauto
    -- end proof

  -- Solve for c
  have h8 : c = 3 ∨ c = -3 := by
    -- Taking square root
    cases h7
    · rcases sq_eq_fifteen h7 with (h₁ | h₂)
      · right; exact h₁
      · left; exact h₂
    · rcases sq_eq_nine h7 with (h₁ | h₂)
      · right; exact h₁
      · left; exact h₂
    -- end proof

  -- Final conclusion
  exact h8

/-- Given a quadratic function f(x) = 4x² - mx + 5 that is increasing on [-2,∞),
    prove that f(1) ≥ 25. -/
theorem quadratic_function_value (m : ℝ) 
    (f : ℝ → ℝ) 
    (h_f : f = fun x ↦ 4*x^2 - m*x + 5)
    (h_incr : MonotoneOn f (Set.Ici (-2))) : 
    f 1 ≥ 25 := by
  -- First, let's prove that m ≤ -16 using the fact that f is increasing on [-2,∞)
  have h_deriv : ∀ x, Set.Ici (-2) x → HasDerivAt f (8*x - m) x := by
    -- begin proof
    intro x hx
    rw [h_f]
    apply HasDerivAt.const_add
    apply HasDerivAt.sub
    · apply HasDerivAt.const_mul
      apply HasDerivAt.pow
      exact hasDerivAt_id
    · exact hasDerivAt_const
    -- end proof

  -- Since f is increasing on [-2,∞), its derivative must be non-negative at x = -2
  have h_deriv_nonneg : 8*(-2) - m ≥ 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    have h_mono := monotoneOn_iff_forall_has_deriv_nneg.mp h_incr
    specialize h_mono (-2) (Set.mem_Ici.mpr (le_refl (-2))) (h_deriv (-2) (Set.mem_Ici.mpr (le_refl (-2))))
    exact h_mono
    -- end proof

  -- Simplify the inequality -16 - m ≥ 0 to get m ≤ -16
  have h_m : m ≤ -16 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof

  -- Calculate f(1) using the definition
  have h_f1 : f 1 = 9 - m := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [h_f]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Use m ≤ -16 to prove f(1) ≥ 25
  have h_final : 9 - m ≥ 25 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof

  -- Complete the proof
  rw [h_f1]
  exact h_final

/-- A helper theorem stating that any natural number ≥ 6 can be reached by starting from 6
    and repeatedly adding 3 -/
theorem square_partition_reachable (n : ℕ) (h : n ≥ 6) :
  ∃ k : ℕ, n = 6 + 3 * k := by
  -- Let's prove by constructing k explicitly
  use (n - 6) / 3
  -- We need to show that n = 6 + 3 * ((n-6)/3)
  have h1 : (n - 6) % 3 = 0 := by
    -- Any number ≥ 6 can be written as 6 + 3k for some k
    induction n with
    | zero => contradiction
    | succ n ih =>
      -- Case analysis on n
      cases n with
      | zero => contradiction
      | succ n =>
        cases n with
        | zero => contradiction
        | succ n =>
          repeat cases n with
          | zero => simp
          | succ n =>
            try simp; try exact ih
  
  -- Use the division algorithm
  have h2 : n - 6 = 3 * ((n - 6) / 3) := by
    -- Apply division algorithm with h1
    exact Nat.div_mul_cancel h1

  -- Algebraic manipulation to get the final result
  have h3 : n = 6 + (n - 6) := by
    simp only [Nat.sub_add_cancel h]

  -- Combine the equations
  rw [h3, h2]
  rfl

/-- Main theorem: A square can be partitioned into n smaller squares for any n ≥ 6 -/
theorem square_partition_exists (n : ℕ) (h : n ≥ 6) :
  ∃ partition : List (ℕ × ℕ), 
    partition.length = n ∧ 
    (∀ p ∈ partition, p.1 > 0 ∧ p.2 > 0) := by
  -- First, use the helper theorem to express n in terms of base case
  have ⟨k, hk⟩ := square_partition_reachable n h
  
  -- Construct the partition inductively on k
  induction k with
  | zero =>
    -- Base case: n = 6
    rw [hk]
    simp only [mul_zero, add_zero]
    -- Explicit construction for n = 6
    use [(1,1), (1,1), (2,2), (2,2), (2,2), (2,2)]
    constructor
    · simp
    · intro p hp
      simp at hp
      rcases hp with hp|hp|hp|hp|hp|hp <;> simp
  
  | succ k ih =>
    -- Inductive step: Show we can add 3 more squares
    have hk' : n = 6 + 3 * k.succ := hk
    have hn : n = (6 + 3 * k) + 3 := by
      rw [hk', Nat.succ_eq_add_one, mul_add, mul_one]
      ring
    
    -- Use induction hypothesis
    rcases ih with ⟨prev_partition, hlen, hvalid⟩
    
    -- Add three more squares by subdividing one square
    use prev_partition.init ++ [(1,1), (1,1), (1,1)]
    constructor
    · simp [hlen, hn]
    · intro p hp
      simp at hp
      rcases hp with hp|hp|hp|hp
      · exact hvalid p (List.mem_init.mp hp)
      · simp
      · simp
      · simp

/-- Corollary: For any n ≥ 6, there exists a partition of a square into n smaller squares -/
theorem square_partition_corollary :
  ∀ n ≥ 6, ∃ partition : List (ℕ × ℕ), 
    partition.length = n ∧ 
    (∀ p ∈ partition, p.1 > 0 ∧ p.2 > 0) := by
  -- Direct application of main theorem
  exact square_partition_exists

/-- Given an ellipse E with equation x²/4 + y²/3 = 1 and line l: x = my - 4,
    the area of triangle DAB (where A, B are intersections of l with E,
    A' is reflection of A about x-axis, and D is intersection of A'B with x-axis)
    achieves maximum when m = ±(2√21)/3 -/
theorem max_area_triangle_ellipse_line {m : ℝ} (hm : m ≠ 0) :
  let S := (18 * Real.sqrt (m^2 - 4)) / (3 * m^2 + 4)
  let m_max := 2 * Real.sqrt 21 / 3
  S ≤ 3 * Real.sqrt 3 / 4 ∧ S = 3 * Real.sqrt 3 / 4 ↔ m = m_max ∨ m = -m_max := by
  
  -- First, let's prove that S ≤ 3√3/4 for all valid m
  have h1 : ∀ m : ℝ, m^2 > 4 → 
    (18 * Real.sqrt (m^2 - 4)) / (3 * m^2 + 4) ≤ 3 * Real.sqrt 3 / 4 := by
    -- begin proof
    intro m hm
    let t := Real.sqrt (m^2 - 4)
    have ht : t > 0 := Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (sub_pos.mpr hm)
    have h_eq : 18 * t / (3 * (t^2 + 4)) = 18 / (3 * t + 16/t) := by
      ring_nf
      rw [mul_div_mul_left]
      · ring_nf
      · exact ne_zero_of_gt ht
    -- Use AM-GM inequality
    have h_am_gm : 3 * t + 16/t ≥ 2 * Real.sqrt (3 * t * 16/t) := by
      apply Real.arithmetic_mean_ge_geometric_mean_two
      · exact ht
      · exact div_pos (by norm_num) ht
    have h_sqrt : Real.sqrt (3 * t * 16/t) = 4 * Real.sqrt 3 := by
      rw [mul_div_cancel_right]
      · ring_nf
      · exact ne_zero_of_gt ht
    rw [h_eq]
    field_simp
    rw [h_sqrt]
    apply div_le_div_of_le_left
    · norm_num
    · norm_num
    · exact h_am_gm
    -- end proof

  -- Then prove that equality holds at m = ±2√21/3
  have h2 : let m_max := 2 * Real.sqrt 21 / 3
            (18 * Real.sqrt (m_max^2 - 4)) / (3 * m_max^2 + 4) = 3 * Real.sqrt 3 / 4 := by
    -- begin proof
    let m_max := 2 * Real.sqrt 21 / 3
    have hm_sq : m_max^2 = 28/3 := by
      field_simp
      ring_nf
    have h_sub : m_max^2 - 4 = 16/3 := by
      rw [hm_sq]
      ring_nf
    field_simp
    rw [hm_sq, h_sub]
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Finally, combine the results
  constructor
  · exact h1 m (by linarith)
  · constructor
    · intro h
      exact h2
    · intro h
      rw [h]
      exact h2

/-- Given a 6×6 square paper folded in half, where the top half is cut into a square and rectangle
    with the rectangle's width being three times the square's width, 
    prove that the ratio of the square's perimeter to the rectangle's perimeter is 1/2. -/
theorem paper_cut_perimeter_ratio : 
  let paper_side : ℝ := 6
  let half_height : ℝ := paper_side / 2
  let square_width : ℝ := paper_side / 4 -- solved from x + 3x = 6
  let rect_width : ℝ := 3 * square_width
  let square_perimeter : ℝ := 4 * square_width
  let rect_perimeter : ℝ := 2 * (rect_width + half_height)
  square_perimeter / rect_perimeter = 1/2 := by
  -- Begin proof
  -- Let's introduce all our variables
  let paper_side := 6
  let half_height := paper_side / 2
  let square_width := paper_side / 4
  let rect_width := 3 * square_width
  let square_perimeter := 4 * square_width
  let rect_perimeter := 2 * (rect_width + half_height)

  -- Verify that square_width + rect_width equals paper_side
  have h1 : square_width + rect_width = paper_side := by
    -- begin proof
    calc square_width + rect_width 
      = paper_side/4 + 3*(paper_side/4) := rfl
      = paper_side/4 + 3*paper_side/4 := by ring
      = 4*paper_side/4 := by ring
      = paper_side := by ring
    -- end proof

  -- Calculate square_perimeter explicitly
  have h2 : square_perimeter = 6 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc square_perimeter
      = 4 * (paper_side/4) := rfl
      = 4 * (6/4) := rfl
      = 24/4 := by ring
      = 6 := by norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Calculate rect_perimeter explicitly
  have h3 : rect_perimeter = 12 := by
    -- begin proof
    calc rect_perimeter
      = 2 * (3*(paper_side/4) + paper_side/2) := rfl
      = 2 * (3*6/4 + 6/2) := rfl
      = 2 * (18/4 + 12/4) := by ring
      = 2 * (30/4) := by ring
      = 60/4 := by ring
      = 12 := by norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Show the final ratio equals 1/2
  calc square_perimeter / rect_perimeter
    = 6/12 := by rw [h2, h3]
    = 1/2 := by norm_num

-- End proof

/-- Given two radioactive isotopes A and B with initial amounts 100 and 200 units respectively,
    and after time t, their amounts become 50 and 100 units respectively,
    then their half-lives ratio TB/TA = 1 -/
theorem radioactive_decay_ratio 
    (TA TB t : ℝ) 
    (h1 : 50 = 100 * (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TA)) 
    (h2 : 100 = 200 * (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TB)) 
    (hpos : t > 0) : TB/TA = 1 := by
  -- First simplify the left equation by dividing both sides by 100
  have eq1 : (1/2 : ℝ) = (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TA) := by
    -- begin proof
    calc (1/2 : ℝ) = 50/100 := by norm_num
      _ = (100 * (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TA))/100 := by rw [h1]
      _ = (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TA) := by field_simp
    -- end proof

  -- Similarly simplify the right equation by dividing both sides by 200
  have eq2 : (1/2 : ℝ) = (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TB) := by
    -- begin proof
    calc (1/2 : ℝ) = 100/200 := by norm_num
      _ = (200 * (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TB))/200 := by rw [h2]
      _ = (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TB) := by field_simp
    -- end proof

  -- From eq1 and eq2, we get that the exponents are equal
  have eq3 : -t/TA = -t/TB := by
    -- begin proof
    have h : (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TA) = (2 : ℝ)^(-t/TB) := by
      rw [←eq1, ←eq2]
    exact Real.log_inj (by norm_num) h
    -- end proof

  -- Multiply both sides by -1 to remove the negative signs
  have eq4 : t/TA = t/TB := by
    -- begin proof
    have h : -(-t/TA) = -(-t/TB) := by
      rw [eq3]
    ring_nf at h
    exact h
    -- end proof

  -- Since t > 0, we can multiply both sides by TB/t
  have eq5 : TB/TA = 1 := by
    -- begin proof
    have h : t/TA * (TB/t) = t/TB * (TB/t) := by
      rw [eq4]
    field_simp at h
    exact h
    -- end proof

  exact eq5

/-- The equation x * 1000 = 5 * (1/x) has a unique positive solution approximately equal to 0.0707 -/
theorem decimal_shift_problem : ∃! x : ℝ, 
  x > 0 ∧ 1000 * x = 5 * (1/x) := by
  -- We'll prove this by showing x = √(5/1000) is the unique solution
  
  -- First, let's show that x = √(5/1000) is a solution
  have h1 : 0 < (5 : ℝ) := by 
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  have h2 : 0 < (1000 : ℝ) := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  have h3 : 0 < 5/1000 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact div_pos h1 h2
    -- end proof

  -- Let's work with x = √(5/1000)
  let x := Real.sqrt (5/1000)

  have h4 : x > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    exact Real.sqrt_pos.mpr h3
    -- end proof

  -- Show that this x satisfies the equation
  have h5 : 1000 * x = 5 * (1/x) := by
    -- begin proof
    have h5_1 : x * x = 5/1000 := Real.sqrt_mul_self h3
    field_simp
    rw [h5_1]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Now prove uniqueness
  have unique : ∀ y : ℝ, y > 0 ∧ 1000 * y = 5 * (1/y) → y = x := by
    -- begin proof
    intro y hy
    have hy1 := hy.1
    have hy2 := hy.2
    field_simp at hy2
    have : y * y = 5/1000 := by
      field_simp at *
      rw [←mul_eq_mul_left_iff] at hy2
      · exact hy2
      · norm_num
    rw [←Real.sqrt_mul_self h3] at this
    exact (Real.sqrt_eq_iff_mul_self_eq h4 hy1).mpr this
    -- end proof

  -- Combine everything to prove existence and uniqueness
  exact ⟨x, ⟨h4, h5⟩, unique⟩

/-- Given a rational function y = (px + q)/(rx + s) where y = 2x is an axis of symmetry,
    prove that p + 2s = 0. -/
theorem symmetric_rational_function 
  (p r q s : ℝ) -- parameters of the rational function
  (hp : p ≠ 0) (hr : r ≠ 0) (hq : q ≠ 0) (hs : s ≠ 0) -- non-zero conditions
  (h_sym : ∀ x y : ℝ, y = (p * x + q)/(r * x + s) → 
    2 * x = (p * (2 * y) + q)/(r * (2 * y) + s)) : -- symmetry condition
  p + 2 * s = 0 := by
  -- We'll prove this by contradiction
  by_contra h_contra
  let h_nonzero := h_contra

  -- For any x, when y = (px + q)/(rx + s), the symmetry condition must hold
  have h1 : ∀ x : ℝ, 2 * x = (p * (2 * ((p * x + q)/(r * x + s))) + q)/
    (r * (2 * ((p * x + q)/(r * x + s))) + s) := by
    -- Apply the symmetry condition with y = (px + q)/(rx + s)
    intro x
    apply h_sym x ((p * x + q)/(r * x + s))
    rfl
  -- end proof

  -- Multiply both sides by denominators to get a polynomial equation
  have h2 : ∀ x : ℝ, 2 * x * (r * (2 * ((p * x + q)/(r * x + s))) + s) = 
    p * (2 * ((p * x + q)/(r * x + s))) + q := by
    -- Multiply both sides and simplify
    intro x
    rw [mul_add, mul_comm]
    ring_nf
  -- end proof

  -- Expand and collect terms to get a quadratic equation
  have h3 : ∀ x : ℝ, (4 * p * r + 2 * r * s) * x^2 + 
    (2 * s^2 - 2 * p^2) * x - (2 * p * q + q * s) = 0 := by
    -- Expand and collect terms
    intro x
    rw [pow_two]
    ring_nf
  -- end proof

  -- Factor out 2(p + s)
  have h4 : ∀ x : ℝ, 2 * (p + s) * (2 * r * x^2 + (s - p) * x - q) = 0 := by
    -- Factor and simplify
    intro x
    rw [pow_two]
    ring_nf
  -- end proof

  -- Since this holds for all x and r ≠ 0, we must have p + s = 0
  have h5 : p + s = 0 := by
    -- If p + s ≠ 0, then the quadratic would be zero for all x, which is impossible
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    specialize h4 0
    specialize h4 1
    linarith
  -- end proof

  -- Therefore p + 2s = 0
  have h6 : p + 2 * s = 0 := by
    -- Substitute p = -s from h5
    rw [h5]
    ring_nf
  -- end proof

  -- This contradicts our assumption
  exact h_nonzero h6

/-- Main theorem about the intersection of sets M and N -/
theorem set_intersection_problem : let U : Set ℤ := {-2, -1, 0, 1, 2}
  let M : Set ℤ := {y ∈ U | ∃ x, y = 2^x}
  let N : Set ℤ := {x ∈ U | x^2 - x - 2 = 0}
  ((U \ M) ∩ N) = {-1} := by
  -- Introduce the sets
  intro U M N
  
  -- First prove that M = {1, 2} in U
  have hM : M = {1, 2} := by
    -- begin proof
    ext x
    simp [Set.mem_setOf]
    constructor
    · intro h
      rcases h with ⟨hxU, ⟨k, hk⟩⟩
      simp at hxU
      subst hk
      cases hxU
      · exact h
      · exact h
      · contradiction
      · contradiction
      · contradiction
    · intro h
      simp at h
      constructor
      · simp [h]
      · cases h
        · use 0; simp
        · use 1; simp
    -- end proof

  -- Then prove that N = {-1, 2}
  have hN : N = {-1, 2} := by
    -- begin proof
    ext x
    simp [Set.mem_setOf]
    constructor
    · intro h
      rcases h with ⟨hxU, hx⟩
      simp at hxU
      have : x^2 - x - 2 = (x+1)(x-2) := by ring
      rw [this] at hx
      simp at hx
      cases hx
      · left; exact hx
      · right; exact hx
    · intro h
      constructor
      · simp [h]
      · cases h
        · ring
        · ring
    -- end proof

  -- Prove that U \ M = {-2, -1, 0}
  have hUM : U \ M = {-2, -1, 0} := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hM]
    ext x
    simp
    constructor
    · intro h
      cases h with
      | intro h1 h2 =>
        simp at h1
        cases h1 <;> simp [*] at *
    · intro h
      simp at h
      constructor
      · simp [h]
      · cases h <;> simp
    -- end proof

  -- Finally prove that (U \ M) ∩ N = {-1}
  calc (U \ M) ∩ N
    = {-2, -1, 0} ∩ {-1, 2} := by rw [hUM, hN]
    = {-1} := by
      -- begin proof
      ext x
      simp
      constructor
      · intro h
        cases h
        exact h
      · intro h
        simp [h]
      -- end proof

/-- For any k ≠ 0, the equation x³ + kx + k² = 0 has at least one real root -/
theorem cubic_equation_has_real_root {k : ℝ} (hk : k ≠ 0) : 
  ∃ x : ℝ, x^3 + k*x + k^2 = 0 := by
  -- Define the cubic function f(x)
  let f := fun x : ℝ ↦ x^3 + k*x + k^2

  -- Prove f is continuous as it's a polynomial
  have hf_cont : Continuous f := by
    -- begin proof
    exact continuous_add (continuous_add (continuous_pow 3) 
      (continuous_const_mul continuous_id k)) continuous_const
    -- end proof

  -- Value at x = 0
  have hf_zero : f 0 = k^2 := by
    -- begin proof
    simp [f]
    -- end proof
  
  -- Value at x = 0 is positive when k ≠ 0
  have hf_zero_pos : f 0 > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    rw [hf_zero]
    exact pow_pos (ne_zero_of_abs_pos (abs_pos.mpr hk)) 2
    -- end proof

  -- For large negative x, f(x) becomes negative
  have hf_neg : ∃ x : ℝ, x < 0 ∧ f x < 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    use -max 1 (|k| + |k^2|)
    constructor
    · simp; exact neg_lt_zero.mpr (lt_trans zero_lt_one (le_max_left 1 (|k| + |k^2|)))
    · let x := -max 1 (|k| + |k^2|)
      suffices : x^3 < -(k*x + k^2) by
        simp [f]; exact this
      have h1 : x ≤ -(|k| + |k^2|) := neg_le_neg (le_max_right 1 (|k| + |k^2|))
      have h2 : x ≤ -1 := neg_le_neg (le_max_left 1 (|k| + |k^2|))
      have h3 : x^3 ≤ -|k*x + k^2| := by
        calc x^3 ≤ -(|k| + |k^2|)^3 := pow_le_pow_of_le_left (neg_le_neg h1) 3
        ... ≤ -|k*x + k^2| := by ring_nf; simp; linarith
      exact lt_of_le_of_lt h3 (neg_lt_zero.mpr (abs_pos.mpr (ne_zero_of_lt
        (calc k*x + k^2 ≠ 0 := by ring_nf; simp; linarith [hk]))))
    -- end proof

  -- By IVT, there exists a root between the negative point and zero
  have h_exists := intermediate_value_Icc hf_cont _ _
  · -- begin proof
    rcases hf_neg with ⟨x, hx_neg, hfx_neg⟩
    exact exists_root_of_sign_change hf_cont hx_neg hfx_neg hf_zero_pos
    -- end proof

/-- For a sequence where a(n+1) = a(n)/(2+a(n)) and a₁=1, 
    we prove that a(n) = 1/(2^n - 1) for all positive integers n -/
theorem sequence_limit (a : ℕ → ℝ) 
    (h_rec : ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ 1 → a (n + 1) = a n / (2 + a n))
    (h_init : a 1 = 1) :
    ∀ n : ℕ, n ≥ 1 → a n = 1 / (2^n - 1) := by
  -- We'll prove this by induction on n
  intro n hn
  -- First, we define a helper sequence b(n) = 1/a(n) + 1
  let b := fun n => 1 / a n + 1

  -- We prove that b forms a geometric sequence with first term 2 and ratio 2
  have h_geom : ∀ k : ℕ, k ≥ 1 → b (k + 1) = 2 * b k := by
    -- begin proof
    intro k hk
    -- Use the recurrence relation
    have h1 := h_rec k hk
    -- Substitute the definition of b
    simp [b]
    -- Use algebra to show equality
    field_simp
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- We prove that b(1) = 2
  have h_b1 : b 1 = 2 := by
    -- begin proof
    simp [b, h_init]
    ring
    -- end proof

  -- Now we prove that b(n) = 2^n for all n ≥ 1
  have h_bn : ∀ k : ℕ, k ≥ 1 → b k = 2^k := by
    -- begin proof
    intro k hk
    induction k with
    | zero => contradiction
    | succ k ih =>
      -- Base case: k = 0, n = 1
      if h : k = 0 then
        simp [h, h_b1]
      else
        -- Inductive step
        have hk' : k ≥ 1 := Nat.succ_le_of_lt (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero h)
        rw [←h_geom k hk', ih hk']
        simp [pow_succ]
    -- end proof

  -- Finally, we solve for a(n)
  have h_final : a n = 1 / (2^n - 1) := by
    -- begin proof
    -- Use the definition of b(n)
    have := h_bn n hn
    simp [b] at this
    -- Solve the equation 1/a(n) + 1 = 2^n
    field_simp
    ring
    -- end proof

  exact h_final

theorem sqrt_diff_inequality {a : ℝ} (ha : a > 6) :
  Real.sqrt (a - 3) - Real.sqrt (a - 4) < Real.sqrt (a - 5) - Real.sqrt (a - 6) := by
  -- First, we prove that a-3, a-4, a-5, a-6 are all positive
  have ha3 : a - 3 > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof
  
  have ha4 : a - 4 > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof
  
  have ha5 : a - 5 > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof
  
  have ha6 : a - 6 > 0 := by
    -- begin proof
    linarith
    -- end proof

  -- The main proof starts here
  -- We rearrange the inequality to avoid dealing with differences of square roots
  have h1 : (Real.sqrt (a - 3) - Real.sqrt (a - 4) < Real.sqrt (a - 5) - Real.sqrt (a - 6)) ↔
            (Real.sqrt (a - 3) + Real.sqrt (a - 6) < Real.sqrt (a - 4) + Real.sqrt (a - 5)) := by
    -- begin proof
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Now we square both sides. Since all terms are positive, this preserves the inequality
  have h2 : Real.sqrt (a - 3) + Real.sqrt (a - 6) < Real.sqrt (a - 4) + Real.sqrt (a - 5) ↔
            (a - 3) + 2 * Real.sqrt ((a - 3) * (a - 6)) + (a - 6) < 
            (a - 4) + 2 * Real.sqrt ((a - 4) * (a - 5)) + (a - 5) := by
    -- begin proof
    have := Real.sq_lt_sq_iff (by positivity) (by positivity)
    simp [sq_add]
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Simplify the algebraic expressions
  have h3 : (a - 3) + 2 * Real.sqrt ((a - 3) * (a - 6)) + (a - 6) < 
            (a - 4) + 2 * Real.sqrt ((a - 4) * (a - 5)) + (a - 5) ↔
            Real.sqrt ((a - 3) * (a - 6)) < Real.sqrt ((a - 4) * (a - 5)) := by
    -- begin proof
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Square both sides again since all terms are positive
  have h4 : Real.sqrt ((a - 3) * (a - 6)) < Real.sqrt ((a - 4) * (a - 5)) ↔
            (a - 3) * (a - 6) < (a - 4) * (a - 5) := by
    -- begin proof
    have := Real.sq_lt_sq_iff (by positivity) (by positivity)
    simp [Real.sq_sqrt (by positivity), Real.sq_sqrt (by positivity)]
    -- end proof

  -- Expand the products
  have h5 : (a - 3) * (a - 6) < (a - 4) * (a - 5) ↔ 18 < 20 := by
    -- begin proof
    ring_nf
    -- end proof

  -- Finally prove that 18 < 20
  have h6 : 18 < 20 := by
    -- begin proof
    norm_num
    -- end proof

  -- Chain all the steps together
  exact h1.mpr (h2.mpr (h3.mpr (h4.mpr (h5.mpr h6))))
